unit_learning_outcomes.description: Appraise funding and financing structures in national health care systems.
Illustrate the theoretical and conceptual underpinnings of health economics.
Apply the principles of economic evaluation to public health allocations to decision-making at the population/community levels.
Analyse how legal frameworks, organisational structures and service delivery systems influence disease prevention and control.
Discuss how key institutional structures, political processes and influences impact on the public health system.
Articulate the role of public policy in promoting and protecting health and preventing disease.

enrolment_rules.description: Admission to MPH or MPH(Res) or MAppEcon

assessments.description: Assignment part A:  a plan for the Health Law and Governance module
Assignment part B: a report for Health Law and Governance module
Participation in class debates and online learning activities such as Q and A forums for Health Law
Reflection of student performance and achievement of course learning outcomes
Online Quizzes for Health Economics module

data.description: This unit aims to introduce students to key concepts of law and economics that are relevant to public health practice. In the law module, you will learn to identify appropriate instruments and mechanisms to write and critique legal documents such as a policy paper. You will explore international, national and local legal frameworks, with a focus on the functions of the United Nations. In the health economics module, you will learn about the structural and financial aspects of a health system, including funding arrangements and economic evaluations that are used to help decision-makers identify cost-effective solutions to health care problems. You will be able to integrate your previous learning in the program to examine ways in which health law, economics and policy advance public health. The unit is delivered through lectures, tutorials and online activities.
